Introduction
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the most noble of Prophets and Messengers. To proceed:
Whoever contemplates many of the issues witnessed in our Islamic arena—whether on the creedal, legislative, intellectual, psychological, or social level—realizes the Muslim's dire need for a legal (Shar'i) grounding for their stance on these issues in the light of the Quran and the authentic Sunnah. Among the issues that have emerged on the Islamic scene is the issue of (Takfir - excommunication/declaring someone a disbeliever). There has been much discussion about it, both in the past and present. It is a place where understanding goes astray and feet slip, potentially leading to conflict, schism, and the legitimization of the forbidden in the name of religion.
People have divided into two extremes and a middle path regarding it; a party believes that Takfir requires declaring the act lawful (Istihlal) or denial (Juhud), so whoever commits any sin, as long as they do not declare it lawful, does not become a disbeliever, even if this sin is explicitly stated as Kufr (disbelief). They may judge acts of Kufr as not being disbelief, classifying them merely as sins less than Kufr. Opposing them in extremism is another group that declares Takfir based on doubts and hunts for...

Preamble
Kufr in the language of the Arabs means covering and concealing. Farmers were called 'Kuffar' because they cover the seeds with soil. From this is His saying: {Like the example of a rain whose [resulting] plant growth pleases the tillers (kuffar)} [Al-Hadid: 20]. The disbeliever (Kafir) was named Kafir because disbelief covered his entire heart, or because he concealed the blessings of Allah upon him. Kufr also comes with the meaning of denial (Juhud). It is said: 'So-and-so 'kafara' me my right,' if he denied it. A 'Kafir' man is one who denies the blessings of Allah. From this is His saying: {And they said, "Indeed we, in all that, are disbelievers"} [Al-Qasas: 48], meaning: deniers.
As for Kufr in terminology, it is the opposite of faith (Iman) in Allah. It is of two types:
Major Kufr (Kufr Akbar) which expels one from the Religion (Millah): This is every disbelief that removes its doer from the circle of Iman, and the legal texts have decreed that its doer is eternally abiding in the Fire. This is the intended subject of the research. It has six types: Denial (Takdhib), Rejection (Juhud), Obstinacy (Inad), Turning Away (I'rad), Hypocrisy (Nifaq), and Doubt (Shakk).
Minor Kufr (Kufr Asghar) which does not expel one from the Religion: This is everything to which the Lawgiver applied the word 'Kufr', while evidence stands that Major Kufr expelling from the Religion was not intended, but rather the Lawgiver intended threat and deterrence.

Chapter One
General Regulations in Takfir in the Light of the Prophetic Sunnah

First Regulation
Takfir is a legal ruling, and a right belonging to Allah, the Lord of the Worlds.
(Takfir is a legal ruling and a pure right of the Lord, Glory be to Him. No entity or group possesses it. Personal taste or reason has no consideration in it, nor does overwhelming enthusiasm or apparent enmity play a part. The injustice of an oppressor who persists in his injustice and deviation does not justify it. Rather, no one is declared a disbeliever except the one whom Allah and His Messenger have declared a disbeliever) (1).
Sheikh al-Islam says: "This is contrary to what some people used to say, such as Abu Ishaq al-Isfarayini and those who followed him, who say: 'We do not declare as disbelievers except those who declare us disbelievers.' For Takfir is not their right; rather, it is the right of Allah. A human does not have the right to lie about someone who lies about him, nor to commit immorality with the family of someone who committed immorality with his family. Indeed, if a man forced him into sodomy, he would not have the right to force him into that...

And if the Rafidah (Shiites) declare Abu Bakr and Umar disbelievers, we do not have the right to declare Ali a disbeliever." (1)

Second Regulation
The Qualification of the One Pronouncing Takfir
Takfir is a legal ruling and a major issue that should not be undertaken except by great Imams and people of knowledge whom Allah ordered to be asked and to whom matters should be referred, when He said: {So ask the people of the message if you do not know} [Al-Nahl: 43]. This regulation will address the one qualified to issue a judgment of Takfir.

A. Definition of Qualification (Ahliyyah):
It is said: 'Ahl' for such: meaning deserving of it; singular and plural are the same in this. And it is said: He is 'Ahl' for that, and 'Ahl' to that. And it is said: He made him 'Ahlan' (qualified) for that matter, qualifying him (Ta'hilan). And he considered him qualified (Ahhalahu): saw him as worthy of it. And 'Ista'halahu': he deserved it (2).

B. Conditions of the One Pronouncing Takfir:
The one pronouncing Takfir must be a scholar (Alim) and a Mujtahid, because Takfir relies on legal proofs, either Quranic of known establishment, or Hadith-based...

C. Texts regarding the qualification of the one pronouncing Takfir:
1. Allah ordered asking the People of Remembrance (Ahl al-Dhikr): {And We sent not before you except men to whom We revealed [Our message]. So ask the people of the message if you do not know} [Al-Nahl: 43]. Sheikh Al-Sa'di said: (Although the cause of this verse is specific to asking about the state of previous messengers to the People of Remembrance—who are the People of Knowledge—it is general for every issue of religion, its fundamentals and branches, if a person does not have knowledge of it, that he asks someone who teaches him) (1).
2. {O you who have believed, obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you} [An-Nisa: 59]. Sheikh Al-Sa'di said: "He ordered obedience to 'those in authority', who are: those in charge of people, including rulers, judges, and muftis. For people's religious and worldly affairs cannot be set right except by obeying them and submitting to them, in obedience to Allah and desiring what is with Him, but on the condition that they do not order disobedience to Allah. If they order that, there is no obedience to a created being in disobedience to the Creator. Perhaps this is the secret behind omitting the verb when ordering obedience to them while mentioning it with obedience to the Messenger, for the Messenger does not order anything except obedience to Allah, and whoever obeys him has obeyed Allah. As for those in authority, the condition for the command to obey them is that it is not a sin." (2)

First Category: That the one pronouncing Takfir is from the righteous of the Ummah but is interpreting incorrectly (Muta'awwil) and mistaken, and he is of those for whom interpretation is permissible: This person and his likes are among those from whom blame and sin are lifted due to his Ijtihad (striving) and expending his effort, as in the story of Hatib bin Abi Balta'a (may Allah be pleased with him). Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) described him as having hypocrisy and asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) for permission to kill him. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to him: "And what do you know? Perhaps Allah looked at the people of Badr and said: 'Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you'" (2). Before discussing the evidence for judging by the apparent, we must understand the meaning of 'Apparent' (Al-Zahir):

A. Definition of 'Apparent':
Zahara (appeared), Yazharu (appears), Zuhuran (appearing), so it is Zahir (apparent). The apparent is the opposite of the hidden (Batin). (1)

B. Judging by the Apparent and Evidence for that (2):
This is one of the great issues in the methodology of Ahlus Sunnah regarding judging people. Their judgments are not based on conjectures, illusions, or claims for which they possess no proof. This is from Allah's mercy and facilitation for His servants and part of charging them with what they can bear and are capable of. All that preceded is intended for the worldly judgment of a person as Muslim or Kafir. As for judging the reality (inner truth), there is no way to that. Imam Al-Shatibi, may Allah have mercy on him, explaining the importance of this principle and the danger of neglecting it, says: (The principle of judging by the apparent is definitive in rulings specifically, and regarding belief in others generally. For the Master of Mankind, despite being informed by Revelation, conducted matters according to their outward appearances regarding the hypocrites...

Fourth Regulation
Differentiating between Absolute Takfir and Specific Takfir (Takfir al-Mu'ayyan)
It is among the principles of Ahlus Sunnah wal-Jama'ah to differentiate between absolute Takfir and the Takfir of a specific individual. Because a Muslim might say a saying or do a deed which the Book, the Sunnah, and the Consensus of the Ummah indicate is Kufr and apostasy from Islam, but there is no necessary correlation for them between saying 'this is Kufr' and declaring the specific person a Kafir. (2)
Absolute Takfir (Takfir Mutlaq): Judging Kufr upon the saying, deed, or belief that negates the foundation of Islam and contradicts it, and upon the doers in a general sense, without specifying anyone in particular.
Specific Takfir (Takfir al-Mu'ayyan): Judging a specific individual as a Kafir for committing something that contradicts Islam, after the conditions of Takfir are met in him and the impediments are absent. (3)

As for the doer, one must look at his intent for what he did and clarify his condition regarding that before being certain. The intent here does not mean merely the intent to perform the action, for action does not occur without this except the action of a madman or a sleeper. It is in reality the decisive will to realize the action such that the human is chosen to do the action or not do it; this intent is the locus of accountability (Taklif). Rather, the intent here means the intent of the action which is the goal of the doer from his action, the motive for him to do it, and the drive to realize it and his desire by it. For this reason, the intent of the action is the reality of the intention (Niyyah) upon which reward, punishment, praise, and blame are based. Chapter Two
Regulations of Specific Takfir in the Light of the Prophetic Sunnah (Conditions and Impediments)
There must be the presence of conditions and the absence of impediments for the Takfir of a specific accountable person (Mukallaf). Here is their clarification:

First: Knowledge is a condition and its impediment is Ignorance:
A Muslim is not declared a disbeliever for a saying, deed, or belief except after the proof is established against him and the doubt is removed from him.
Knowledge (Ilm) linguistically: The opposite of ignorance. It is: perceiving a thing as it really is, with a decisive perception. (1)
Technically: Some people of knowledge said: It is recognition (Ma'rifah) and it is the opposite of ignorance. Others of the people of knowledge said: Knowledge is clearer than to be defined. (2)
Ignorance (Jahl) linguistically: It is the emptiness of the soul from knowledge. (3)

For this reason, if a man embraced Islam and did not know that prayer was obligatory upon him, or did not know that wine is forbidden, he does not become a disbeliever for not believing in the obligation of this and the prohibition of that. B. Some Important Issues
1. Merely pronouncing the two testimonies (Shahada) is sufficient to judge a person as Muslim:
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "It is known by necessity from the religion of the Messenger (peace be upon him), and agreed upon by the Ummah, that the foundation of Islam, and the first thing creation is commanded with, is the testimony that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. By it, the disbeliever becomes a Muslim, the enemy becomes an ally (Wali), and the one whose blood and wealth were lawful becomes protected in blood and wealth." (2)
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar says: "...And in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (the Hadith of sending Mu'adh to Yemen), among the benefits is: Sufficing with the acknowledgment of the two testimonies to judge the Islam of a disbeliever." (3)
Some researchers confuse the worldly judgment with the judgment in the Hereafter, so they think...

Or they think that the conditions mentioned by scholars for the word of Tawhid—such as knowledge, sincerity, certainty, etc.—mean that a person is not judged as Muslim until after these conditions are understood [by him]. But the truth is that mere pronunciation of the word of Tawhid does not save the servant before Allah unless its conditions are met. As for the worldly judgment, mere pronunciation is sufficient to judge a person as Muslim until what contradicts that becomes apparent to us after the proof is established. Thus, we realize the error of those who believe that those who fall into some forms of Shirk, like vowing and slaughtering for other than Allah and circumambulating graves, among those who testify the testimony of Tawhid, are original disbelievers (Kuffar Asliyun) on the basis that they did not understand Tawhid." 2. Establishment of Proof differs according to times, places, and persons:
Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "Many people may grow up in places and times where much of the knowledge of prophethood has been obliterated, to the extent that there remains no one to convey what Allah sent His Messenger with of the Book and Wisdom. Thus, he does not know much of what Allah sent His Messenger with, and there is no one there to convey it to him. Such a person does not become a disbeliever. Therefore, the Imams agreed that whoever grows up in a remote desert far from the people of knowledge and faith, and was new to Islam, and denied these apparent, widely known rulings...

3. The Manner of Establishing Proof against a Specific Person:
Proof must be established that negates any doubt or interpretation from the one against whom it is established. Ibn Taymiyyah says: "Likewise, regarding statements whose sayer becomes a disbeliever: The man may not have received the texts necessitating knowledge of the truth; or they may be with him but not established [as authentic] to him; or he was unable to understand them; or he may have encountered doubts for which Allah excuses him. So whoever among the believers strives in seeking the truth and errs, Allah forgives him his error whatever it may be, whether in theoretical or practical issues. This is what the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and the majority of the Imams of Islam are upon. They did not divide issues into fundamental issues (Usul) whose denial constitutes Kufr, and branch issues (Furu') whose denial does not constitute Kufr." (2)

As for before the proof is established against him, he is excused and rewarded even if he is mistaken. The nature of establishing proof against him is that it reaches him such that he has nothing to contradict it. And success is with Allah." (1)
From here, the role of scholars in establishing proof against the ignorant person becomes clear, such that doubts are negated from him and ignorance is removed.

Second: Intent (Qasd) is a condition, and its impediment is Mistake (Khata):
Among the regulations of specific Takfir according to Ahlus Sunnah is that the person must have intended his action and not be mistaken in it.
Intent (Qasd) linguistically: The straightness of the path. Qasada, Yaqsidu, Qasdan, so he is Qasid (intending). The Almighty's saying: {And upon Allah is the direction of the [right] way (Qasd al-Sabeel)} [Al-Nahl: 9] means upon Allah is the clarification of the straight path. Qasd also means justice (2).
Technically: Will (Irada). (3)

Sheikh al-Islam says: "As for 'Takfir': The correct view is that whoever strives (makes Ijtihad) from the Ummah of Muhammad (peace be upon him) and intends the truth but errs, does not become a disbeliever; rather, his error is forgiven. But whoever the Message brought by the Messenger becomes clear to, yet opposes the Messenger after guidance has become clear to him and follows other than the way of the believers: he is a Kafir. And whoever follows his desire, falls short in seeking the truth, and speaks without knowledge, he is a disobedient sinner; he may be a Fasiq (rebellious sinner), or he may have good deeds that outweigh his bad deeds." (2)
After presenting the evidences, it becomes clear to us that the mistaken person is excused, and his ruling is the ruling of the ignorant and the interpreter (Muta'awwil). He is not declared a disbeliever except after the proof is established against him. If he was a Mujtahid in matters where Ijtihad is permissible, he has the reward of his Ijtihad even if he erred. But if he was not a Mujtahid and erred, he sins for his negligence.

Third: Will (Irada) is a condition, and its impediment is Compulsion (Ikrah):
Among the conditions of specific Takfir according to Ahlus Sunnah is that the person must be willing his action, not coerced into it.
Will (Irada) linguistically: Volition (Mashia'ah).
Technically: In the usage of jurists, it is "Intent" (Qasd), meaning the determination to do the act and directing towards it (1).
As for Compulsion (Ikrah) linguistically: It is coercion and forcing without love, consent, or choice. (2)
Technically, it is: "Compelling another to do what he does not want." Or "Forcing [someone] to do a thing coercively" (3).

A. Types of Compulsion:
The majority of Usulis (legal theorists) and jurists divided compulsion into two types: Compulsion that leaves no choice (Mulji' - Resorting/Complete), which is Perfect Compulsion, and Compulsion that leaves some choice (Ghayr Mulji' - Non-Resorting/Incomplete), which is Imperfect Compulsion.
Resorting/Complete Compulsion (Perfect): That which befalls the self (life) of the coerced: leaving the person with no capability or choice, such as threatening a person with killing him or cutting off a limb...

...of his limbs like his hand or leg, or with severe beating leading to his destruction, or destruction of all his wealth. So when it seems most likely to him that what he was threatened with will happen to him, it is permissible for him to do what he was pushed to do by the threat, considering him to be in a state of legal necessity (1).
Non-Resorting/Incomplete Compulsion (Imperfect): It is the threat or warning with something less than loss of life or limb, such as frightening with beating, binding, imprisonment, or destruction of some wealth. This type spoils consent (Rida) but does not spoil choice (Ikhtiyar) because there is no necessity to perform what he was coerced into, due to his ability to endure what he was threatened with (2).
Attached to this type may be the threat of imprisoning the father, son, wife, sister, mother, or brother. There is a dispute regarding considering this section as a type of compulsion (3). Juristic Preference (Istihsan) counts it as compulsion, because the coerced person is afflicted with distress...

• The Interpreter Not Excused for his Mistake
However, if the interpreter has no apparent proof for his interpretation, such that he interprets definitive matters (Qat'iyyat) regarding which ignorance is not an excuse for people like him, then he sins and may become a disbeliever by his interpretation depending on his state. Because there is no disagreement among Muslims that if a man openly denies apparent, mass-transmitted obligations, and apparent prohibitions, and the like, he is asked to repent, otherwise he is killed as a disbelieving apostate. This is contrary to the Murji'ah who say: 'No sin harms with Faith, just as no obedience benefits with Kufr' (3).
The commentator of Al-Tahawiyyah said: "A man may be a believer inwardly and outwardly but interprets with an interpretation in which he errs, either striving (Mujtahid) or negligent and sinful. It is not said: His faith is nullified merely for that, unless a legal proof indicates that. Rather, this is of the same genus as the saying of the Kharijites and Mu'tazilah (i.e., absolute Takfir). Nor do we say he does not disbelieve (like the Murji'ah). Rather, justice is the middle path: That false, innovated, prohibited statements which imply negating what the Messenger affirmed or affirming what he negated, or commanding what he forbade or forbidding what he commanded: the truth is spoken regarding them, and the Threat indicated by texts is established for them, and it is explained that they are Kufr, and it is said: Whoever says them is a Kafir...

Conclusion
Praise be to Allah, abundant, good, and blessed praise. And peace and blessings be upon the most noble of Prophets and Messengers. After Allah has bestowed upon me the completion of this research, among the most important results and recommendations are:
1. Clarifying the moderation of Ahlus Sunnah wal-Jama'ah between the extremism of the Kharijites and the negligence of the Murji'ah in the issue of Takfir.
2. Takfir is a legal ruling and a right belonging to the Lord of the Worlds. It is not permissible for the common Muslims to delve into it, because it is a slippery slope causing stumbles. Rather, it is undertaken by the people of knowledge who are firmly grounded.
3. Differentiating between Takfir by description (general) and Takfir by person (specific).
4. Caution in declaring a specific person a disbeliever, and the danger of declaring him a disbeliever without proof.
5. The principle regarding a Muslim is uprightness. He is not declared a disbeliever except after the meeting of the conditions of Takfir—Knowledge, Intent, Will, and Lack of Interpretation—and the absence of impediments—Ignorance, Mistake, Compulsion, and Interpretation.
